fields.Quotation: The truth is rarely pure and never simple. Modern life would be very tedious if it were either, and modern literature a complete impossibility!  _Oscar Wilde
It is absurd to divide people into good and bad. People are either charming or tedious. _Oscar Wilde
After a good dinner one can forgive anybody, even ones own relations. _Oscar Wilde
In matters of grave importance, style, not sincerity is the vital thing. _Oscar Wilde
"Reeling and Writhing, of course, to begin with," the Mock Turtle replied; "and then the different branches of Arithmetic--Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision.  _Lewis Carroll
To be clever enough to get all that money, one must be stupid enough to want it. _G. K. Chesterton
We live, as we dream--alone.  _Joseph Conrad
Words, as is well known, are the great foes of reality. _Joseph Conrad
. . . dont you forget what's divine in the Russian soul--and that's resignation. _Joseph Conrad
And a word carries far--very far--deals destruction through time as the bullets go flying through space.  _Joseph Conrad
Man is sometimes extraordinarily, passionately, in love with suffering. _Dostoevsky
. . . human speech is like a cracked tin kettle, on which we hammer out tunes to make bears dance when we long to move the stars. _Gustave Flaubert
They slipped briskly into an intimacy from which they never recovered. _F. Scott Fitzgerald

A funeral is not death, any more than baptism is birth or marriage union. All three are the clumsy devices, coming now too late, now too early, by which Society would register the quick motions of man.  _E. M. Foster
The tree rustled. It had made music before they were born, and would continue after their deaths, but its song was of the moment. _E. M. Foster
What is the good of your stars and trees, your sunrise and the wind, if they do not enter into our daily lives? _E. M. Foster
. . . the rich ate and drank freely, accepting gout and apoplexy as things that ran mysteriously in respectable families .  _George Eliot
"The human heart," he murmured, "is the tomb of many feelings."_John Galsworthy
The proper study of mankind is books. _Aldous Huxley
Why can't somebody give us a list of things that everybody thinks and nobody says, and another list of things that everybody says and nobody thinks?  -Oliver Wendell Holmes
A moment's insight is sometimes worth a life's experience. -Oliver Wendell Holmes
I talk half the time to find out my own thoughts, as a school-boy turns his pockets inside out to see what is in them. _Oliver Wendell Holmes, Sr.

Men are idolaters, and want something to look at and kiss and hug, or throw themselves down before; they always did, they always will; and if you don't make it of wood, you must make it of words. -Oliver Wendell Holmes, Sr.
A weak mind does not accumulate force enough to hurt itself; stupidity often saves a man from going mad. _Oliver Wendell Holmes, Sr.
Knowledge and timber shouldn't be much used, till they are seasoned. _Oliver Wendell Holmes, Sr.
Under certain circumstances there are few hours in life more agreeable than the hour dedicated to the ceremony known as afternoon tea. _Henry James

Let your boat of life be light, packed with only what you need - a homely home and simple pleasures, one or two friends, worth the name, someone to love and someone to love you, a cat, a dog, and a pipe or two, enough to eat and enough to wear, and a little more than enough to drink; for thirst is a dangerous thing. _Jerome K. Jerome
Shakespeare is the happy hunting ground of all minds that have lost their balance.  _James Joyce
"Thats the way we all begin," said Tom Platt. "The boys they make believe all the time till they've cheated 'emselves into bein' men, an so till they die - pretendin' an pretendin'   _Rudyard Kipling
There are two races of people, only two, and they live side by side. His calls mine 'neurotic'; mine calls his 'stupid'.   _Sinclair Lewis
They think me mad--Starbuck does; but I'm demoniac, I am madness maddened! That wild madness that's only calm to comprehend itself! _Herman Melville
Yea, foolish mortals, Noah's flood is not yet subsided; two thirds of the fair world it yet covers. _Herman Melville
You needn't tell me that a man who doesnt love oysters and asparagus and good wines has got a soul, or a stomach either. He's simply got the instinct for being unhappy highly developed. _Saki

Remember that you are a human being with a soul and the divine gift of articulate speech: that your native language is the language of Shakespeare and Milton and The Bible; and dont sit there crooning like a bilious pigeon. _George Bernard Shaw
I have to live for others and not for myself: thats middle class morality. _George Bernard Shaw
The more things a man is ashamed of, the more respectable he is. _George Bernard Shaw
What is life but a series of inspired follies? _George Bernard Shaw
All great truths begin as blasphemies. _George Bernard Shaw
The confusion of marriage with morality has done more to destroy the conscience of the human race than any other single error. _George Bernard Shaw

It was the incarnation of blind and insensate Greed. It was a monster devouring with a thousand mouths, trampling with a thousand hoofs; it was the Great Butcher--it was the spirit of Capitalism made flesh. _Upton Sinclair

And whenever he spoke (which he did almost always), he took care to produce the very finest and longest words of which the vocabulary gave him the use, rightly judging that it was as cheap to employ a handsome, large, and sonorous epithet, as to use a little stingy one. _William Makepeace Thackeray
There is no happiness in love, except at the end of an English novel. _Anthony Trollope
The bishop did not whistle: we believe that they lose the power of doing so on being consecrated. _Anthony Trollope
When angry, count four; when very angry, swear. _Mark Twain

Its lovely to live on a raft. We had the sky up there, all speckled with stars, and we used to lay on our backs and look up at them, and discuss about whether they was made or only just happened. _Mark Twain
When you consider things like the stars, our affairs dont seem to matter very much, do they? _Virginia Woolf
Mediocrity knows nothing higher than itself; but talent instantly recognizes genius.  _Sir Arthur Conan Doyle

But Rosa soon made the discovery that Miss Twinkleton didnt read fairly. She cut the love-scenes, interpolated passages in praise of female celibacy, and was guilty of other glaring pious frauds.  _Charles Dickens

In other countries, art and literature are left to a lot of shabby bums living in attics and feeding on booze and spaghetti, but in America the successful writer or picture-painter is indistinguishable from any other decent business man.  _Sinclair Lewis

fields.Title: Background Books
fields.Description: If you are interested in getting an overview of a particular literature, Background Books is the best place to start. Here you will find a select bibliography of books that will provide you with a historical and critical perspective of that literature as a whole. After reading a few of these background books, you will be in a much better position to appreciate and enjoy the works of individual authors in that literary tradition.

fields.Title: Authors
fields.Description: You may access the Authors either alphabetically or by area. One click on the top menu gives you a nice set of black-and-white photographs of these great writers of our times whose writings have touched the hearts and minds of millions all over the world. Just one more click on an author's name will take you straight to a list of his or her books, complete with book reviews and prices. Here you can leisurely browse through all their titles which are currently available. If after reading the reviews, you feel intrigued or attracted enough to explore further, the Buy Now button will take you directly to the details page of the book on Amazon's website. Here you can read many more editorial and reader reviews of the title selected. At this point, you can either add the book to your shopping cart or buy it right away, if you feel so inclined. Coming back to the World Literature website is easy. All you have to do is to hit the back button on your browser.

fields.Title: Award Winners
fields.Description: However, if you wish to start with the very best, the crème de la crème, go to the Award Winners. Out of the thousands, these are the authors and books that have won some of the most prestigious awards, such as the Nobel Prize in Literature, Man Booker Prize, the Man Booker International Prize, Commonwealth Writer's Prize, the International IMPAC-Dublin Literary Award, the National Book Award (NBA), the National Book Critics Circle (NBCC) Award, the PEN-Faulkner Award for Fiction or the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction. Check them out. You'll have a hard time deciding where to start. Well, just start anywhere, you can't go wrong!

fields.Title: Book Reviews
fields.Description: If you are interested in the very latest and greatest, there are Book Reviews from a variety of authoritative sources to guide you. Read the reviews and then decide which book has the best claim to your limited free time this week.

fields.Title: Bestsellers
fields.Description: If you would like to know which books are selling the most, go to the Bestsellers lists from popular sources such as NPR, New York Times, Publisher's Weekly, Times Literary Supplement, USA Today, etc. You will find everything you are looking for and a lot more!

fields.Title: Book News
fields.Description: If you are a news junky and would like to get your daily fix of the latest news in the book world, go to Book News. Here every day you are bound to find some juicy tidbits that would reinforce your belief in the fact that life is still worth living.

fields.Title: Links
fields.Description: Last, but not least, the Links menu will provide you with a number of entry points to some very interesting and valuable resources on the Internet. Follow any of these links to discover some real treasures and experience the wonderful joys of serendipity, which only the Web can provide.

fields.Title: Subjects
fields.Description: Alternatively you may like to approach the vast variety of world literature through the Subjects menu. A click on this menu will allow you to browse through the hundreds of books available under the following subject headings: Anthologies, Bibliographies, Biographies, Criticism, Fiction, History, Non-fiction, and Poetry.

fields.Title: World Literature Your Guide to the Very Best
fields.Description: This website attempts to bring in one place all the major contemporary writers of world literature, especially those who either write in English or whose works have been translated into English. It provides easy access to books of all the leading novelists, poets, playwrights, and critics of our times through the largest online bookstore on the planet.
